data.title: What’s on TV tonight: Strictly Amy: Cancer and Me, Equal Play and more
data.meta_description: Your complete guide to the week’s television, films and sport, across terrestrial and digital platforms
data.text:
Bank Holiday Monday

Strictly Amy: Cancer and Me

BBC One, 8pm

At the beginning of 2023, the day before she was due to go on her honeymoon, Amy Dowden felt a lump in her breast. The 34- year-old Strictly Come Dancing professional had stage-three cancer. This remarkably raw documentary, which began filming a mere six days after her diagnosis, is an intimate portrait of the following 15 months – a period of hardship and resilience. The Strictly star is a warm ray of Welsh sunshine, yet even her heroic positivity falters in the face of unrelenting misfortune.

The gruelling course of chemotherapy she undertakes, for instance, could damage her fertility, potentially upsetting her long-held plan for a family; and Dowden’s determination to keep her hair – helped by the use of a cold cap, which freezes the scalp during chemo – proves too agonising to bear. Then comes a terrifying brush with sepsis. But hardest of all for Dowden is having to take a hiatus from dancing – and Strictly. Indeed, it feels particularly cruel that when she finally gets the chance to return, she breaks her foot while rehearsing. Yet rest assured, Dowden’s optimism has come good: she is now cancer-free and will return to the ballroom as a pro this autumn. SK

Equal Play

Channel 4, 6pm

Ahead of the Paralympics, this punchy half-hour documentary explores the barriers that disabled people face in trying to access sport. As athlete Hannah Cockroft argues: “If we said 75 per cent of all children were not physically active in school, there would be uproar. But as soon as you put in the word ‘disabled’, everyone just seems to go ‘ah well’.”

The Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo: 2024

BBC One, 6.30pm; Scot, 7pm

JJ Chalmers and Jennifer Reoch talk us through the annual music spectacular from Edinburgh Castle. This year, the Massed Pipes and Drums will be joined by Swiss drummers Majesticks, Indian Bhangra dancers and a range of regimental bands from the US army.

Titanic: The Musical

Sky Arts, 7pm

Filmed during its 2023 UK tour, this extravagant stage musical retells the sinking of the RMS Titanic. Eschewing Jack and Rose for something more sweeping and holistic, the highlight is the poignant duet Still, themed around the true story of a wealthy couple who chose to remain on board so that younger people could live.

The Kingdom: The World’s Most Powerful Prince

BBC Two, 9pm

The concluding part of this engrossing profile about Saudi Arabia’s Mohammed bin Salman explores his multitude of contradictions: he has relaxed some laws for women (allowing them to drive, for instance) and imported Western sport, but remains ruthless towards domestic dissent.

Platform 7

ITV1, 9pm

The supernatural ITVX drama finally gets its terrestrial premiere. It tells the story of a dead woman (Top Boy’s Jasmine Jobson) who haunts the platform of a train station. That is, until she is joined by a depressed curmudgeon played by Phil Davis. The mysteries of why they killed themselves will play out across four episodes, airing each night this week.

Adam Hills: Foot Fault

Sky Documentaries, 9pm

The only way to play high-level tennis as a disabled person is to play in a wheelchair. As The Last Leg host Adam Hills argues, however, this excludes prosthetic leg-users like him. Hence this winningly playful documentary in which he tries to promote para-standing tennis: a sport that can be played by disabled people with the ability to stand.

Matilda (1996) ★★★★

ITV1, 3pm

Nearly as sweet as the giant chocolate cake devoured by one of the story’s heroes (“You can do it, Bruce!”), this adaptation of Roald Dahl’s classic children’s novel still has charm in abundance. It stars Mara Wilson as Matilda, a child genius and avid reader who overcomes some horrendous parenting (from the hilarious pairing of Danny DeVito and Rhea Perlman) and a sadistic headmaster (Pam Ferris) to realise her true potential.

Shrek (2001) ★★★★★

Sky Showcase, 5.15pm

With a blend of youthful adventure and arch wit, DreamWorks tell the story of Shrek (Mike Myers), a curmudgeonly green ogre living reclusively in a forest in a country populated by refugees from other fairy tales. Particularly delicious are John Lithgow’s merrily evil, exceedingly short Lord Farquaad and some witty new twists on a bunch of old favourites including Pinocchio, The Three Little Pigs and Three Blind Mice.

The Personal History of David Copperfield (2019) ★★★★

Film4, 6.40pm

The Thick of It writer Armando Iannucci perhaps wouldn’t be your first choice to direct a Victorian classic. But he injects Dickens’s schoolboy story with plenty of wit and vivid colour, helped along by a transfixing performance from Dev Patel in the lead. A cross between Fawlty Towers-esque farce and period piece, the stellar cast also includes Tilda Swinton and Ben Whishaw.

Tuesday 27 August

Only Murders in the Building

Disney+

The hit whimsical murder-mystery series starring Steve Martin, Martin Short and Selena Gomez as a trio of amateur true-crime podcasters in New York City returns for a fourth season – and fans are unlikely to be disappointed. Already one of America’s most-watched dramas, thanks in part to the addition of Meryl Streep and Paul Rudd to the cast last time out, this is a series brimming with creative confidence and a clear desire to flex its entertainment muscles with more twists and still more star power boosting its appeal. Even the tantalising cliffhanger on which season three concluded is kept in play for a good part of the new series opener.

The opening episode’s main plot follows the core trio from NYC to Tinseltown after a major Hollywood studio bids to turn their podcast into a mega-budget movie. Eventually, of course, the action pivots back to the familiar – if deadlier – comforts of the Big Apple, with three more hilariously eccentric starry guest stars – Eugene Levy (Schitt’s Creek), Eva Longoria (Desperate Housewives) and Zach Galifianakis (The Hangover) – in tow. How long for, who cares? For now, it’s humming along beautifully. GO

The Secret Life of Midges

BBC Two, 7pm; not Wales

A deep-dive into the bloodsucking insect that plagues parts of Scotland in the summer. Dr James Logan explores how to avoid being dined on by the “terror of the Highlands” and what makes some folk more attractive to midges than others.

Celebrity MasterChef

BBC One, 8pm

Battling for attention with Cooking With the Stars on ITV1, the third heat gets under way with socialite Emma Thynn, actor Tamer Hassan, singer Jake Quickenden, comedian Jamie MacDonald and presenter Christine McGuinness heading into the kitchen. Figs, white pudding and hake are among the ingredients they must turn into delicious meals.

Food Unwrapped’s Party Platter

Channel 4, 8pm

A celebratory special looking at the art and science of party food. Kate Quilton discovers how the shape of chocolates can change how they taste, Jimmy Doherty unravels the secrets of samosas, Briony May Williams learns how to mix a classic martini and Matt Tebbutt heads to the lab for a gastronomic science lesson.

Freddie Flintoff’s Field of Dreams on Tour

BBC One/BBC Two Wales, 9pm

As they reach the halfway point on tour, Freddie Flintoff begins to prepare the boys for their toughest cricket match yet, and teaches them some rules of behaviour ahead of an important social event involving Kolkata high society. Consistently entertaining and surprisingly moving fare.

Warship: Life in the Royal Navy

Channel 5, 9pm

In the final episode of this absorbing series about the modern Royal Navy, JJ Chalmers has another go at the gruelling marine commando training test that he passed with flying colours 18 years ago, and visits the Navy’s high-tech weapons development unit. In the North Sea, meanwhile, Julia Bradbury helps the crew of HMS Prince of Wales prepare for the last leg of their epic journey.

Murder on Ward 4

Channel 5, 10pm

There are echoes of the recent Lucy Letby case in this shocking true-crime film looking back to 1991, when a spate of unexplained emergencies struck a children’s ward at Grantham Hospital, resulting in four deaths. The police investigation focused on nurse Beverley Allitt, known as the “Angel of Death” in the tabloids.

Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003) ★★★★

Film4, 6.20pm

Peter Weir sensibly cast Russell Crowe in the type of Gladiator-esque flick that suits him best: a glowering, muscle-encased hunk clad in period get-up. In this grand, vivid drama he plays Jack Aubrey, captain of a British frigate in the Napoleonic Wars. This film pulls off a rare Hollywood feat in almost matching its superb source (Patrick O’Brian’s novels) for quality. Paul Bettany co-stars.

Arcadian (2024) ★★

Sky Cinema Premiere, 9.45pm

Always dreamed of watching Nicolas Cage fight off slimy post-apocalyptic monsters with his bare hands? If so, Benjamin Brewer’s horror-survivalist flick might be right up your street – just ignore the convoluted plot. Arcadian mostly focuses on twins Joseph (Jaeden Martell) and Thomas (Maxwell Jenkins), Cage’s sons, as the three grapple with terrifying monsters who stalk their remote home at night.

Police Academy (1984) ★★★

ITV4, 10pm

This puerile, oh-so Eighties comedy follows police cadet Carey Mahoney (Steve Guttenberg) and his motley band of misfit police recruits as they cause their commanding officers a heap of trouble. The six sequels, each increasingly desperate, can be missed. But the original retains plenty of its zany period charm and even features amusing turns from Kim Cattrall, Bubba Smith and Michael Winslow. Buckle up!

Wednesday 28 August

Paralympics Paris 2024: Opening Ceremony

Channel 4, 6.30pm

The opening ceremony of the Paris Olympics attempted to turn the City of Light itself into a venue, with more than 10,000 athletes parading on boats down the Seine. Daring in theory, but disastrously rainswept in reality. The organisers of tonight’s Paralympic opening ceremony will be holding out hope for clearer skies. It continues the theme of eschewing

a traditional stadium setting. Instead, more than 4,000 para-athletes will parade along the Champs-Élysées to the Place de la Concorde. Then follows a spectacle of lights and music. Clare Balding presents tonight’s coverage, which will kick-start 12 days of Paralympic sport across Channel 4, More4 and streaming.

Acerbic chat show The Last Leg has also relocated to Paris, and will be broadcasting live nightly to recap each day’s events. The first episode will follow the ceremony (at 10.30pm) and will feature the likes of comedians Rosie Jones and Josh Pugh in the studio, plus former rugby union player and fellow Paralympics presenter Ed Jackson. At 11.30pm, you can also catch a repeat of The Last Leg host’s Adam Hills’s moving documentary Grow Another Foot, about his quest to play rugby. SK

Costco vs the Supermarkets: Who Does It Cheaper?

Channel 5, 7pm

Wholesale chain Costco provides its members with exclusive bargains; the catch is that you have to buy in bulk. As this one-off argues, however, the retailer is in danger of being undercut by supermarkets. Is the cost of a membership still worth it? Or are you better off ditching the van and heading to Lidl?

The Repair Shop

BBC One, 8pm

The most remarkable heirloom in need of repair this week is a broken silver ring brought in by mother-daughter duo Halina and Lesley. It was a gift given to Halina’s mother during the Second World War, a thank you for risking her life to pass food to families imprisoned in Warsaw’s Jewish ghetto.

Celebrity Race Across the World

BBC One, 9pm

The epic race enters its third week. Tonight, the celebrities must travel 2,400 km from the small town of Lençóis, Brazil, to the bustling metropolis that is São Paulo. There is a particularly poignant moment in which father-and-son Jeff and Freddy Brazier mark the death of the latter’s mother, Jade Goody. For Freddy, it is strange to reminisce about someone he barely knew.

Cause of Death

Channel 5, 9pm

Tonight’s episode of the true-crime docu-series concerns 34-year-old Natalie Anne Caine, who died soon after suffering from heart palpitations. The coroner attempts to determine the cause of death – was her neurofibromatosis a factor? Elsewhere, the team must try to find the next of kin of a man found collapsed at home.

Kidnapped: The Chloe Ayling Story

BBC Three, 9pm & 9.30pm

Kidnapped model Chloe Ayling (Nadia Parkes) is now free. But, as tonight’s concluding two-part instalment of the true-crime drama shows, her ordeal was only just beginning: a savage press whirlwind and a high-stakes trial to clear her name ensued.

Rob & Romesh vs Hollywood Stunts

Sky Max, 9pm

In the saturated genre of “comedians going places and doing things”, Rob Beckett and Romesh Ranganathan are by far the funniest and most effortless. This long-running series, in which the pair try out a range of careers, returns with a mission to turn them into Hollywood stuntmen. Watch out for the hilarious moment in which Ranganathan’s heart is stolen by actor Ryan Gosling.

Percy Jackson & the Lightning Thief (2010) ★★★

Film4, 6.45pm

In this first adaptation of Rick Riordan’s bestselling children’s books, Percy (Logan Lerman) learns from centaur Pierce Brosnan that he’s the son of Poseidon and has been framed for the theft of Zeus’s lightning bolt. He teams up with a wise-cracking satyr and Athena’s warrior daughter to save the world from ruin. The far superior TV version, Percy Jackson and the Olympians, is available on Disney+.

Ad Astra (2019) ★★★★

Film4, 9pm

James Gray gives us an elegant and staggeringly visualised adventure that deconstructs the dogged kind of alpha-heroism glorified by far too many US space movies. Brad Pitt plays Roy McBride, an astronaut sent on an odyssey to Mars where he must confront his renegade father (and save Earth while he is at it). The strong supporting cast includes Ruth Negga, Tommy Lee Jones and the late, great Donald Sutherland.

The Shallows (2016) ★★★★

GREAT! Movies, 9pm

Let’s cut right to the chase: here is a film in which a bronzed Blake Lively spends an hour and a half fighting a great white shark off the coast of Australia. Are you sold? Jaume Collet-Serra’s survival thriller features every drop of profundity suggested by its title, but who cares. It’s a sinewy, aerobicised production with oodles of charm and excitement – and not a drop of pretension. Óscar Jaenada and Brett Cullen co-star.

Thursday 29 August

Kaos

Netflix

From hit tween drama Percy Jackson and the Olympians on Disney+ to Margaret Atwood and Madeline Miller’s bestselling novels, the world can’t get enough of modern retellings of Greek myths. Netflix has decided to muscle in on the hype with this terrifically daft, deft take on ancient Greece’s ultimate Big Guy. Jeff Goldblum plays Zeus as a neurotic, self-obsessed manchild who spirals into paranoia when he wakes up one morning and spots a wrinkle in the mirror; cue pity for his poor friend-turned-prisoner Prometheus (Stephen Dillane), who Zeus begins to believe is plotting his downfall.

Created by self-confessed Classics geek Charlie Covell (The End of the F***ing World), Kaos recruits a heavenly supporting cast – Janet McTeer plays Zeus’s plotting wife Hera, Juice’s Nabhaan Rizwan delights as their hedonistic son Dionysus and David Thewlis brings heft to the role of Underworld ruler Hades – to weave together several classic Greek myths, including that of Orpheus and Eurydice. The majority of the plot, though, hinges on Zeus’s fall from grace; and the three humans tasked with saving him (and Olympus) before it’s too late. PP

The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power

Amazon Prime Video

Feted as the most expensive TV show ever made, with each episode costing Amazon owner (and Tolkien superfan) Jeff Bezos an estimated £49 m, the first series of this Lord of the Rings prequel looked terrific, but the characters and action sequences often felt flat. With Charlie Vickers’s young baddie Sauron now taking centre stage, here’s hoping this second series feels more magical.

Bangers & Cash: Live

U

Fans of the amicable Mathewson family will enjoy this live spin-off from their auction show Bangers & Cash, where they allow customers to bid on classic cars and memorabilia at their North Yorkshire HQ.

Michael Mosley: Wonders of the Human Body

Channel 5, 8pm

Michael Mosley’s final series before his death earlier this year continues, as he offers up more hands-on analysis of how to keep your body healthy. Tonight’s episode sees Mosley turn his attention to gene therapies that have the potential to reverse blindness.

Who Do You Think You Are?

BBC One, 9pm

Spice Girl Melanie Chisholm (better known as either Mel C or Sporty Spice) dives into her family tree in another moving episode. In her hometown of Liverpool, she discovers that her great-grandmother earned her independence outside of the home through work as a local moneylender, and looks into why her ancestors decided to undertake a journey familiar to many Scousers: leave Ireland for Merseyside.

Disappearance of Shannon Matthews

Channel 5, 10pm

The disappearance of nine-year-old Shannon Matthews in Dewsbury in 2008 shocked Britain – but not as much as the revelation that her mother had made it up. This gripping two-parter talks to family friends, police and journalists about the case.

The Poughkeepsie Shuffle: Tracing the French Connection

BBC Four, 10.40pm

This 2000 documentary explores the tempestuous production of William Friedkin’s classic thriller. Film critic Mark Kermode dives into the history of the 1960s gang bust that inspired the film, but it’s the interviews – with the late Friedkin and stars Gene Hackman and Roy Scheider – that are the most gripping. The film itself precedes at 9pm.

The 7th Voyage of Sinbad (1958) ★★★★

Film4, 12.45pm

The fabulous mythological creatures of stop-motion maestro Ray Harryhausen may look a bit clunky to modern eyes, but they’re still awe-inspiring in a primal way that CGI can’t match. Kerwin Mathews plays our hero, Sinbad, forced to battle the Cyclops, a dragon and a skeleton swordsman to rescue his magic lamp (and lover). All set to a Bernard Herrmann score. They don’t make them like this any more.

The French Connection (1971) ★★★★★

BBC Four, 9pm

This gritty thriller set the template for countless hard-bitten crime films of the 1970s and beyond. Gene Hackman is superb as “Popeye” Doyle, a surly copper determined to trap a suave French drug dealer (Fernando Rey) who is smuggling heroin across the Atlantic. The white-knuckle car chase, in which Popeye tails an elevated train, is top notch. It scooped five Oscars. Also on Monday on BBC Two at 9pm.

Film of the Week: The Commandant’s Shadow (2024) ★★★★★

Sky Documentaries, 9pm

Those who have watched British director Jonathan Glazer’s extraordinary Oscar-winner The Zone of Interest will feel a jolt of familiarity at this chilling documentary. The Commandant’s Shadow follows Hans-Jürgen Höss, the now elderly son of the Nazi Auschwitz commandant Rudolf Höss (who was executed in 1947), as he returns to his tranquil childhood home in Poland, which was located next door to the death camp. Similar to Glazer’s powerfully moralistic drama, which posed questions about whether humanity would ever commit such atrocities again – in the present or future – this documentary, made by film-maker Daniela Volker, wonders whether the Höss family, like many other Germans, simply mastered how to ignore what was going on around them. “I had a really lovely and idyllic childhood in Auschwitz,” says Höss at the beginning. Despite this, we’re shown the impact his childhood (and parents) had on his relationship with his own son, Kai, while a meeting with the London-based Holocaust survivor Anita Lasker-Wallfisch, who calls their healing encounter “beautiful”, makes for immensely moving and inspirational viewing.

The Spy Who Dumped Me (2018) ★★★

Film4, 11.05pm

Proving that “spy spoof” is every bit as safe a bet for film-makers as “spy drama”, Susanna Fogel’s amiable send-up sees Mila Kunis’s everywoman forced into an international conspiracy when her boyfriend (Justin Theroux) dumps her – and turns out to be a CIA agent. It’s about as subtle as the Europop bangers that soundtrack it, but for a switch-your-brain-off 90 minutes it’s more than adequate.

Friday 30 August

Beethoven’s Ninth Unwrapped

BBC Four, 8pm

The 200th anniversary of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony was celebrated in a stunning Prom last week. It’s a beast of a piece – remarkably composed when Beethoven had lost his hearing – and even fairweather fans of classical music will recognise the fourth movement’s Ode to Joy, adopted by the EU as its official anthem. The work has a British connection: although it was first performed in Vienna in May 1824, it was commissioned by the Philharmonic Society of London.

What sets this special recital apart is that it is performed by the Aurora Orchestra, under British conductor Nicholas Collon; the orchestra describes itself as “an innovative and boundary-breaking ensemble”, as it performs music from memory, without sheet music or stands. Soloists Masabane Cecilia Rangwanasha, Marta Fontanals-Simmons, Brenden Gunnell and Christopher Purves are joined by the combined forces of the BBC Singers and the National Youth Choir of Great Britain to form the chorus for the final movement. Actor Rhiannon May and actor/BSL interpreter Thomas Simper also take part in the concert which is introduced by musician and presenter Linton Stephens. VL

K-Pop Idols

Apple TV+

Hot on the heels of BBC One’s reality show Made in Korea: The K-Pop Experience comes this six-part docu-series that goes behind the scenes of the billion-dollar industry and meets some of its most in-demand performers, including Jessi, Cravity and Blackswan.

Our Lives: The Seal Whisperer

BBC One, 7.30pm; NI, 8.30pm; Wales, 8pm

Northumberland GP Ben Burville spends most of his spare time bobbing beneath the waves with grey seals. This charming one-off, filmed over six months, shows how he has formed a special bond with the marine mammals – and captured never-seen-before seal behaviour, including one taking a nap underwater.

Rescue 999: Seconds to Save a Life

Channel 5, 8pm

More episodes from the busy – and sometimes dangerous – lives of emergency crews. Tonight’s stories include an air ambulance team called to the aid of an injured motorcyclist in Cambridgeshire and a tricky evacuation by the Edale Mountain Rescue team, who have to carry a hurt walker on a stretcher along a narrow, rocky path.

Gardeners’ World

BBC Two, 9pm

More from Monty Don’s garden as he prepares for next year by getting some daffodils in the ground and offers useful advice on how best to deal with bindweed. Elsewhere, Frances Tophill visits pioneering horticulturist Josh Sparkes at his experimental plot in Devon to discuss the topic of sustainable food production.

Terror at 30,000 Feet

Channel 5, 9pm

More airborne terror, this time for real, as the series concludes with a description of the 1989 Kegworth disaster, in which 47 people were killed. The incident occurred after flames were seen coming from one of the plane’s engines on a flight from Heathrow to Belfast. The events of the crash – which eventually led to a change in pilot training – are told through archive, reconstructions and interviews with experts and passengers.

Hostage

More4, 9pm

The tense Swedish thriller set on a hijacked plane continues as Erik (Adam Lundgren) and Osman (Peshang Rad) try to take action without alarming their fellow passengers. On the ground, meanwhile, the investigation into the hijackers takes a bizarre turn.

The Deliverance (2024)

Netflix

Inspired by the Ammons haunting case that gripped the US in 2011 – in Gary, Indiana, a mother and her three children claimed their house was haunted by malevolent beings – Lee Daniels’s supernatural horror is a must-watch for any fans of The Blair Witch Project or Paranormal Activity. Andra Day plays the haunted, troubled mother whose home (and young children) become possessed by demons. Glenn Close and Caleb McLaughlin also star.

Salome (1953) ★★★

Talking Pictures TV, 4.25pm

William Diertle’s Biblical drama might seem outdated today, but Rita Hayworth’s lead turn remains a delight. Hayworth plays the rebel daughter of King Herod (Charles Laughton), who gets cast out of Galilee after an affair and struggles to regain her father’s favour; as well as avoiding her jealous mother’s (Judith Anderson) wicked machinations. George Duning wrote the terrific musical score.

Madame Web (2024) ★★

Sky Cinema Premiere, 8pm

Never has the idiom “all publicity is good publicity” proven as true as with Madame Web. Dakota Johnson’s Spider-Man spin-off was derided by critics and social media users, yet still lured people into cinemas. Johnson’s protagonist, who can see into the future after being bitten by a magical spider while in utero (yes, really), is tasked with protecting three dreary but super-powered teens (Sydney Sweeney among them).

Broken (2012) ★★★★

BBC Two, 12.05am

Theatre director Rufus Norris’s film debut is set in a modest suburban cul-de-sac with three adjacent houses which must bear the burden of representing broken Britain. Tim Roth is on fine form as a crumpled solicitor, and his daughter Skunk (Eloise Laurence) is a cheerful beacon of goodness in an otherwise downbeat film. Their scenes together are beautifully played. Cillian Murphy and Rory Kinnear also star.

Television previewers

Stephen Kelly (SK), Veronica Lee (VL), Gerard O’Donovan (GO), Poppie Platt (PP) and Gabriel Tate (GT)
